subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
Within Chinese, {{zh-ref|Carr (1990)}} relates it to:
* {{och-l|咢|to beat the drum}}, either because drumming was associated with dragons or because some drums were made of crocodilian skins ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}).
* Words for “fear”, e.g. {{och-l|愕|startled; terrified}}, {{och-l|噩|frightening; startling}}.

Outside of Chinese, {{zh-ref|Carr (1990)}} also relates it to:
* {{cog|tai-pro||*ŋwak|mythical water creature}} (reconstruction from {{zh-ref|Chamberlain, 1977}}), which {{zh-ref|Pittayaporn (2009)}}, reconstructing the root as {{m|tai-pro|*ŋɯəkᴰ||crocodile}}, holds to be a loan from Chinese.
* Proto-{{w|Austro-Tai}} {{m|und|*(m)baŋiwak||shark; crocodile}}, posited by {{w|Paul K. Benedict}} and proposed by him to give rise to the Tai word, as well as {{cog|ja|-}} {{ja-r|鰐|わに|crocodilian; shark}}, {{ja-r|魚|うお|fish}}.

subSections.text: {{zh-der|澳洲鱷魚|鱷溪|鱷魚|大鱷|揚子鱷|鱷梨|鱷魚眼淚}}
